title: Excellent end of life care
body:
My Mom was taken to A & E first, she was then taken to AMUa ward and then lastly spent her last day in Priory 5 Ward.  I cannot praise all the staff in each ward enough for the care and dignity that was given to my Mom and also the support we were shown as a family.
Thank you all so much

readBy.name: Sandwell and West Birmingham Hospitals NHS Trust

title: Long wait
body:
Thank you for completing an online consultation. One of your doctors will now review your answers. Your practice will respond by phone, text or email before 6:30PM on Thursday, 24th of June.

The Surgery has a message for you about your recent online consultation.

The message is:

"Thank you for your recent eConsult request. The doctor will call you on 02.07.2021 to discuss you medical issues. thank you"

This is the GP. You need see or speak to the GP urgently , and this is the answer. Very disappointed

author: wearingbm94
title: It all helps with my care
body:
Just come to the DRC ( Dimond Resource Centre )on women’s service compound. Today is a special day because its Florence nightingale’s birthday AKA national nurse day. I had a game of scrabble and won by 1 point and this afternoon a danceathon. I donated 3 quid for cavel nurse trust.
Just about to leave the DRC, its been a good day had some drinks hot and cold, have done some reading and had education with Richard and Chelsea. Used gym. Buffet at DRC was good I just wanted to say thankyou as we been in DRC all day we decanted due to legionella testing on the ward. I’m back on the ward now.
all helps with my care this kind of thing
Thank you again

author: asteropekt46
title: horticulture on Wednesdays
body: The DRC TED ( Dimond resource centre Therapy education department )team take us to horticulture on Wednesdays, I find it very relaxing and very therapeutic. The animals make me feel calm but I’m scared of the chickens. I do go near them so I can get used to them. All the staff are very supportive. I like coming to the DRC and doing my therapies and playing board games, and colouring. I think the hairdressers are brill and do a good job. I enjoy going to the salon.

title: unreceptive
body: Very beligerant reception who have a don't care attitude to your problems so therefore you don't get any help or to see a doctor;just weknow best

title: Great experience
body: Very professional and helpful. From admin to GP everyone I came into contact with was very professional and really left me feeling reassured about my health

title: Well done Spa Medica, Bradford
body: Perfect in every way, great team, thank you all. Good atmosphere created by your professionalism. A well-oiled machine moving like clockwork, seamlessly and efficiently thus creating calm, quiet confidence in those trusting their eyes to your care. Edward Holmes.

title: Safety Issues long wait for appointment
body:
Apart from waiting 5 months for an X-ray appointment then having to travel for 3 hours (20 miles across London) to get there. Terrible Service.

However, I arrive and the main staircase Fire Doors are wedged open both at the top and bottom. I imagine this is the “protected staircase’ and includes a lift lobby! Additionally, is also marked as the only emergency exit from the waiting room area.

Shocked that an organisation we are forced to use IN Health 193 Lincoln Road - EN1 1LJ does not take our fire safety seriously. Especially considering it is a medical establishment that is likely to have people with mobility issues. 

I would avoid !

author: Seanthewanderer
title: Crohns disease and Gender reassignment
body:
As someone who is all too familiar with auto imune diseases it has been especially refreshing to have the IBD team at the NHS as my team.  
I am a 26 year old Trans man, I was diagnosed with incredible urgency and care even during the pandemic with Crohns disease in 2020. Since then the IBD team have been a saving grace. Most if not all of my family are afflicted with auto imune diseases and I'm sorry to say that most of their teams have let them down in numerous capacity's over the years! And so I was worried that I would have a similar experience, no communication, mis diagnosis, sub par care, wrong medications and review etc etc.  
This was absolutely not the case.  
The IBD team at the RAH in paisley have exceeded any and all expectations I could have had and have made an already really hard period of my life so much easier, I really can't thank them enough. Especially Susan, who has been at the end of the phone and reachable within minutes, and has seen me anytime I've had a hospital appointment even making me feel confident and comfortable to do my own Injections.  
Thank you guys, it really makes having this horrible disease that much more manageable when you know the support behind you is so strong and invested in your care.

author: Mooncake13
title: The best start in life
body:
Very happy that the midwives discussed the benefits of breastfeeding my baby and advising the importance of collecting colostrum from 36 weeks in syringes provided by the community midwives. By collecting colostrum it aided in breastfeeding, making sure I had enough for baby and helped keep baby calm during medical examinations, and assisted midwives help me recover from my complicated delivery of baby.  
Due to collecting colostrum early in the last few weeks of pregnancy, when my baby was born and I was unable to breastfeed, the midwives were able to express colostrum from me so my husband was able to feed baby.  
I believe this initiative will help moms going forward to give their babies the best start in life and promoting breastfeeding reduces financial strain on families as breastfeeding does not add additional costs to families. I do think that providing new moms that are breast feeding a basic vitamin supplement like in pregnancy would be beneficial for breastfeeding even if just for the first month to ensure vitamin D, vitamin C, folic acid and any other basic vitamins to promote recovery and breast milk quality.

title: Mr Lilley
body: The worst experience of a surgery ever. Tried to pick up a sick note for a friend, 7-10 days wait, fine on the 10th day still not ready, if it was for a cold ok, but when as explained to the receptionist it's for a lady with cancer who's benefits could be in jeopardy as no longer able to work replied 7- 10 days I said this is 10 days and still not ready, when will it be ready, she replied I don't know, how long does it take to do a sick note? Just a blank look, also regular training with customer services wouldn't go amiss, never have I ever experienced anything like this before.

title: Great service
body:
Unfortunately I ended up in A & E after a fall. From the A & E staff to all the staff at the hospital in A & E, X-ray, CT scan, theatre & Newton 3 ward every single person was absolutely amazing. I could not fault any of them in any way possible. I was seen promptly by all the departments involved, all the staff spoke to me with kindness & respect & the care was amazing by them all. I am forever grateful for the level of professionalism, the service of care I received by everyone involved & did not feel any awkwardness whatsoever from anyone. Keep doing what your doing because it really does make a positive difference to people’s lives. I will need to return to hospital soon & have no hesitation in my mind that it will be another awesome experience. 

From my heart to yours, thank you so much & I am truly grateful & appreciate all of your efforts in helping me get better.

readBy.name: Sandwell and West Birmingham Hospitals NHS Trust

title: Fantastic Service
body: I have been having treatment from this clinic since 2009. The service I have received is A1. I have Had many trained staff giving me injections all of whom are of a very high standard, friendly and informative. I am to have eye treatment to save my sight until my demise. Thank you, clinic, 8 for everything.

title: lateness
body: had a appointment for 16 45 and at 17.00 asked how long i would be waiting. up to two hour to wait with 6 people before me i am a Carrera for my partner so i cant wait 2hrs .if i was 5minites late the appointment would be cancelled very poor

title: Amazing care
body: Today I called at 9.30 in need of an emergency appointment the receptionist was friendly and helpful and put me down for a telephone consultation, gp called shortly after she was so kind and I felt genuinely cared for, the Dr arranged for a face to face the same day and truly went above and beyond to help me .. thank you

title: Wasted a week off work
body: Had to attend the clinic on Monday for a covid swab, which meant a taxi there and back. Then three days isolation. Turn up on the Thursday for my operation to be told they can't do it as they missed vital information from my notes! So another two taxi journeys and a week off work wasted!

title: I cannot believe the surgery doors are opened
body:
Avoid this surgery , just like the above and below reviews. 
 I called just like the receptionist tell you 
At 8am and 2pm there is never appointments 
I cannot believe when i rang and said i want to book as i have been trying to get an appointment for the last week and no success so I explained and said can i have a one in the one week or the next slot 
Response was i have also nothing prebookable 
Doctors appointments can be only booked 2 weeks in advance. 
The week or to before i got sent a text message saying please contact the surgery reception to discuss a test result i rang and they said they have nothing to book 
At this point can you even blame me for being frustrated and angry 
Why is the staff allowed to send sms or call patients if there is no where to book them , what surgery honestly work this way i do not understand , over the years the surgery has gone worst I'm not sure due to the new partners or the management , you ask for a manager and she never takes a call , i actually feel for the receptionist that they seem to have no support from the management . I decided to turn up at the surgery to a patient before me kicking of a major fuss for the same thing as me and i was absolutely disgusted that a surgery can operate this way , i witnessed on how the receptionist felt and no care of management to even avoid this sort of behaviour . Despite on how angry i was i was absolutely respectful towards the staff at reception as i feel they can only do what they instructed to do  . How on earth is this patient care ? 
I’m currently looking for another surgery 
Bad experience

title: Amazing care
body: I was treated in gateway f today. The appointment was on time, the nurse consultant was incredibly supportive and gave me a great treatment plan, and the nurse that cared for me was very thoughtful and informative. I was so nervous beforehand but felt totally at ease throughout and was even served a drink and biscuits in the recovery area. I couldn’t have asked for anything more. Thank you.

author: dh111
title: Covid swabbing prior to a hospital procedure
body:
All the staff were very helpful but I have a few suggestions. I was asked to carry out a home testing kit on the Friday in preparation for my hospital procedure on the Monday. I was sent the kit along with instructions. The instructions stated that the test should be dropped off at one of the various location within an hour of completing the test and to also drop off before 10am that day, which I did.  
On the Saturday I got a call from the hospital questioning whether I had done the test or not which was rather worrying. It seemed the test had somehow gone missing.  
I was asked to go to the drive through Covid test station at Barnstaple, that day to complete a 2nd test. The staff member (Sarah) I spoke to on the phone was very helpful and went above and beyond to help me. The other staff member (Kirsty) at the testing centre was also super helpful, so thank you for that.  
Luckily both test results came back negative and I was able to have my procedure carried out on the Monday as planned.  
My questions are: as there was little information on what the procedure is if a test does go missed, would it not be a good idea to make it clearer to patients that in this unlikely event the 2nd test will be prioritised so not to hold up any forth coming procedure or appointments?  
I felt I had to push a little bit to find out if the test results would be back in time and after waiting so ,long for the actual procedure in the first place it would have been such a shame if it couldnt have gone ahead.  
My other question is why are some patients given a home testing kit and some sent to the drive through, what are the distinctions and reasons for which type of test a patient is allocated?  
My final thought is, the instructions that came through with the home testing kit stated to drop off the same day before 10am then on the bottom of the same page it stated 11am, has this not been proof read? I feel this could be quite misleading to some people.  
Thank you again to all the staff who helped me on this occasion, you were all very helpful.  
I would also like to say how nice it is to have the opportunity to call up Care Opinion and speak to an actual person to share my story/feedback rather than having to fill in a paper tick box form, and to know that I will also receive a response from staff is even better :-)

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

title: Very dissapointing
body: I am highly disappointed and frustrated by the services of Leister Terrace healthcare and I can say it's absolutely no care provided since the last 6 months we registered and they have only made the process more difficult for us, delayed response, very very callous attitude which is unexpected of a medical center.

title: Bad service
body:
This is the second time in a month that i have received awful service from the Hessle Grange surgery. On June 11, 2021 I was booked for push doctor appointment by Surgery. After waiting 1 and half hour there i was told that no doctor is available and some one will call me on weekend to rearrange the appointment.But no body called back. Then I called again on Monday to book the appointment. Today 24-06-21 I was booked for face to face consultation at 5:10pm I rushed from work to reached there on time and on arriving there I was told that sorry some body booked you at 10:00 am.
I asked them to check the phone recording as it is not my mistake but the receptionist said that we cant do any thing you have to book the appointment again tomorrow at 8:00am. I am very disappointed.

title: Fantastic
body:
I have seen several members of the practice myself and with my 4 month old son during pregnancy/postnatal period. Despite very challenging times during the pandemic, I have always got an appointment quickly, staff have been friendly and helpful. Repeat prescription requests are sorted very promptly, with GPs clearly doing admin over the weekend to keep up judging by the dates on the prescriptions! Thank you all. 
(My only request would be for the toilets to be reopened now COVID is easing)

title: Poor level of service
body:
Telephoned the surgery today, it took nearly an hour to get through to speak to someone. That's better than last week when I kept getting a message telling me the call waiting was full.
Yet again no appointments available, I was told to call back tomorrow, I told the receptionist I'd waited nearly an hour only to be told they are very busy.
When will someone ensure we get an improved level of service.

title: Excellent Practice
body: The all practice from the beginning to the end was very professional and the all therapy was well documented and helpful. Will strongly recommend

title: Excellent practice
body: I had my bloods taken this evening . I did not feel the prick . It was well done . The person who did it knows her job . Keep up the good work .

title: Rather a waste of time
body: Could not have fields test at original eye appt as machine broken. Eventually given second appt. Not very local surgery to my home. Appt was on time. Test completed. Was asked for my eye prescription but was not told to take it when the appt was made. Went to see consultant. Said fields test was not good not bad. Looked in my eyes Could offer no reason for fields results not being  totally satisfactory. Seemed exhausted himself. Head in hands. Eventually said perhaps we should see you in 6 months. Have now made private appt with my own optician to get a sight test and my glasses checked as l am now worried in case there is a problem with my sight.

author: Killeavy
title: Failure to follow up on medication
body:
I attended an annual blood test for my HB1ac test. Part of this process also included checking of my blood pressure. It was diagnosed as slightly high and a scheduled visit to the nurse was arranged for the following week.  
Two days after I attended the initial visit, I attended a work related medical. Again, my blood pressure was taken and returned values of 169/105. I was referred to my doctor and restricted at work. A few days later I attended a blood pressure test again at my surgery. My blood pressure returned results of 159/101. The results were escalated to the GP from the nurse. I hadn’t heard anymore information until I collected a repeat prescription for my diabetes. Enclosed was Ramapril and the instructions on the box were to take one per day.  
After 1 week, I contacted my surgery to ask if I was required to have my blood pressure checked periodically to determine if the tablets were effective. I was told I would be checked annually but they would put the question to a GP. I had no response for 5 days. I contacted the surgery again but they had no information about the phone call 5 days earlier. They said they would pass it to a GP.  
I was contacted later that day and told I would be checked annually and the dosage I was given was correct. Ten minutes later I was called by the surgery again. The details had also been passed to the Practice nurse who insisted I make an appointment to see her. What annoys me more is there was intention of any follow up to find out if the medication was making an improvement in my blood pressure or hypertension and quite frankly the gp’s dismissive response I believe is not acceptable, given this could cause long term damage to my heart or lifespan.  
The nurse has taken the correct course of action in my opinion. Is this worth complaining about? I feel the service has been unacceptable in this instance for an illness which could be life threatening if not treated correctly.

title: Excellent Nurse-led Child Immunisation…
body: Thanks to both nurses today who cheerfully, quickly and competently vaccinated my three year old having taken the time to explain exactly what was happening to both me and most importantly, to her. Really grateful to have had two nurses doing the two jabs at once. Thank you.

title: Great service
body: I used engage consult to make contact with a dr. The doctor called me later that day. Very thorough investigation of my issue and treatment arranged. I was kept up to date following this appointment and the dr went out of his way to ensure I received his messages. Thank you

title: Fabulous service
body:
I have always found Alma Road to be fabulous. I was worried about pain I was experiencing and was offered a telephone appointment the same day. When it hadn't subsided 2 weeks later, I rang and was given an appointment with my GP the next day and she said she would chase up the scan she'd ordered. Two days later I got a scan cancellation and a few days later my GP rang to discuss the results.
I never have any issues getting appointments, especially for my children and I find all the staff friendly and helpful. I have been with the practice for nearly 50 years and I wouldn't go anywhere else. Thank you for your brilliant service

title: Great Service
body: I called to make an appointment (15 in the queue, on hold 30 mins, I just put on speaker and carried on with what I was doing), got a telephone  appointment for first thing the next morning, which then resulted in a physical appointment later that day and a referral. Staff were helpful and professional, thank you.

title: Simply Dreadful
body: Absolutely horrendous practice. Wait forever on the phones, never speak to a regular GP, just ‘what whoever is around’, usually a nurse, and never EVER given results from tests, with no follow ups or information. Cannot wait to leave this practice. Stay away.

author: festivitypc63
title: My daughters visit to minor injuries
body: We were greeted today with a nurse who, I felt, couldn’t get rid of us quick enough! They asked what had happened and my daughter explained to them that her knee had popped out at a ballet class while doing leaps. They asked if she had taken any painkillers and I’d explained that calpol wasn’t helping and she was scared to swallow tablets ( she’s 12 years old). They replied saying that it can’t be that sore then. They played about with her leg for a few seconds then sent us away and told her to take paracetamol, I had already said she can’t swallow tablets! I was appalled at their lack of empathy, my daughter is struggling to walk, has been in tears with the pain all day and rather than help her, I feel they insulted her twice and sent her away!

title: Waiting more than 3 days for an MRI
body: Care is fine but waited 3 days for an MRI they've kept me waiting for 3 days, delayed for no reason. Patient given no information at all

readBy.name: Barking, Havering and Redbridge University Hospitals NHS Trust

title: Excellent Practice
body: Always well attended to and quite caring. Each time I book an appointment I'm seen and listened by a member of their team of professionals to diagnose what the problem may be. This goes for other members of my immediate family as well.

title: Medical Negligence
body: Lost my bloods, don’t know what they’re doing. Meant to be referred to the hospital! Not taking my problem seriously.

title: 12 year old with broken foot, turned away!
body: I took my 12yr old son to Montagu hospital after being told to go there by a 111 nurse. He had broken his foot. We were turned away and told to go to DRI because their protocol was not to treat him if he'd fallen over a metre in height. What a waste of time and frustration caused after we were told to go there

title: No care at all
body: The gps provide very little care at this surgery. On the 15/06/2021 I had a telephone consultation for my son which the doctor phoned at 19:15pm, I truly believe he was saying it was viral because of the time he phoned and obviously couldn’t see my child as the surgery was nearly shutting. We ended up being seen in a&e that evening. Even though we are in a pandemic I think the gps should take more care of there patients and actually see them to consult them especially when they are children/elderly. On Friday 18th June I asked for a gp to ring me again which yes one of your gps rang me in the afternoon and yet again sent me elsewhere for my son to be seen at a clinic that wasn’t even local to me. Which they gave me antibiotics. So now that’s twice the gps haven’t seen my son and he’s had treatment elsewhere. What exactly does this surgery provide? Reception staff phoned me from the surgery on Monday to book in for a follow up for today. Which the doctor phoned me around about 12, the phone literally rang about 3 times and by time I went to answer they put it down. I phoned back and was informed they will let the gp know I’ve phoned back and ask them to give me a call back. Which a gp never gave me a call back which isn’t a surprise at all. Just to mention though the reception/admin staff are all great and do a really good job of running the place.

author: ChapfromSheffield
title: Fitzwilliam centre
body:
I have been receving help and support from the Fitzwilliam centre for a number of years. Ive always felt that the care provided there was of the highest quality in often very difficult circumstances and probably doesnt recieve the plaudits it deserves.  
I have used drugs since i was 18. Actually well before then but only in earnest then.I started with cannabis and grew up in the 90s when there were a lot of all sorts of drugs about. I dabbled with ectasy, speed and cocaine and then heroin. When i was about 25 I stopped using heroin without getting a habit and my drug use calmed down. I was really only using cannabis at nighttime and the occasional binge at the weekend. I was drinking pretty heavily and using valium too to dampen my anxiety.  
When I was turned 40 I had a very low period. My relationship was struggling and I felt very lonely. I realised that I could buy heroin online via the darkweb and have it delivered the next day. So I did. This turned into a habit and over a couple of years I got myself into a real tangle. I started knocking about with people who scored on the street and got a few phone numbers. Before long I was scoring in stairwells and using every day. I was somehow managing to hold down a job and help look after my three kids.  
I was using then, i now know through the help of Eileen and James at Fitzwilliam ,because i was deeply unhappy and wanted to self medicate to keep those feelings at bay.  
I've been on a script for buprenorphine and diazepam from Fitzwilliam since about 2013 I believe. I have been through ups and downs during this period but feel that I've made a lot of progress and am currently doing well. A lot of this is down to the dedication and wise guidance of Eileen and James.  
Eileen is a prescribing nurse with a therapeutic background and James is a therapist. They have really supported me at a level i needed to make the steps i needed to make to stop using and get myself back on track. This was much about addressing the underlying reasons for my use and I cant thank them enough for their dedication and professional skill. I believe that I may well be dead or homeless or in prison without them. I found out that you cant maintain a heroin habit and go anywhere but down. The only question is how fast.  
I just want to put on record my thanks for this and also for the future of any funding that may be in question for this service. I've spent many hours in the Fitzwilliam centre and I've seen the wide range of clients there. From folk that are homeless and living fix to fix to professionals who've picked up an opiate habit somewhere along the line and everyone in between. We're all the same really. But the calmness and caring nature of the staff there is unbelievable. I have had support from plenty of others along the way - Dave, Rod, Sarah, Andy and Sid are some of them. They've all been great.  
But I want to say a special word of thanks to Eileen and James. I went to my GPs surgery for the first time a few months back and was surprised to see that the level of care and attention there wasn't anywhere near that of Fitzwilliam. Its not a fashionable area of healthcare and is unlikely to be a priority for some commissioners. The lives of many of its clients are very tough and they present a variety of challenges on a daily basis. I don't know how many give feedback but I've never seen anyone treated with anything other than kindness and respect even when behaving occasionally pretty badly.  
I'm now living by himself and with access to my three children regularly - a better father to them and a happier person.  
In summary my view is that this is an excellent service and vital for supporting people who get themselves in difficulties with opiates. It can happen to anyone. I would recommend that this service is maintained in its current structure if the opinions I've heard from opiate users in other cities who have had their services run by other companies is anything to go by. I'm certain i got a far better service than my friend in other cities for example. On a wider level have a look at other countries to see what can happen if you don't fund and prioritise this work properly. The worst drugs deaths figures in Europe.

readBy.name: Sheffield Health and Social Care NHS Foundation Trust
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: Debzter
title: Recovery from alcohol
body: Came in to get a rescue kit due to an experience a few days ago finding someone who had overdosed. I've since been told they are OK. As I am a service user myself, I love this place and it is such a beneficial service and is a great place to be. It's a family unit and love everyone here. Fantastic new reception.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: giraffegd97
title: Coeliac group meeting
body: This was a zoom meeting. I really enjoyed the fact that I was able to attend this meeting from the comfort of my own home.   I learnt about the importance of zantham gum in baking and got a demonstration on how to make gluten free bread.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Marthina
title: My midwife
body: I just want to say, again, a huge thank for the NHS. I had my baby 4 months ago in Edinburgh, but I am living on Jura. My midwife, Jennie, from Islay - I'll be grateful for the rest of my life for how much attention and affection she had during my pregnancy. She made me feel "at home", as I am a foreign, she was so special, always explaining to me everything as many time as I needed. I've never imagined having this privilege, being supported and not feeling alone, at all. She made a difference for me and my baby, thank you, Jennie.

title: Terrible
body: Cleanliness is terrible, staff at point of booking in are rude, inept and unprofessional. All of patients personal details are repeateded back to them at a volume all can hear including ailments and associated details. Very poor.

title: Superb care
body: Really positive experience at the PCEU today. Seen quickly, very professional service and great communication. A+

author: Slash
title: Colonoscopy
body:
Faultless service  
Everything was spot on

title: Rude staff
body: Was not very impressed with the way I was treated, I have been in pain and got thrown out basically without being checked over. I explained to the nurse I was suffering with pain in my wrist, and also having pregnancy pains and got told to go home as she couldn’t do anything!

author: Jensg54
title: Primary care
body:
Since my first telephone call from the Pharmacist, Catherine, to discuss my long term medication requirements and who subsequently referred me to Esther, the Primary Care Occupational Therapist, I cannot believe the quality of service I have received from them.  
Esther came out to access me and from there on I have had nothing but the best of attention from her. She suggested various household implements to assist my mobility, Also, as I have been stumbling & falling quite a bit she had an alarm system installed for me and as my bedrooms are upstairs she arranged, through Linda the Social Care Occupational Therapist, for a stair lift to be installed. This all happened within a few weeks, much to my amazement.  
She also arranged for me to have visits from Linda, a Physiotherapist, who, as well as giving me some very light exercises, was watching how I moved about the house with my two sticks & furniture walking. She suggested I would be better with a three wheel walker to help keep me more upright and also assist my movement around the house safely. This is now on order for me.  
I can’t believe the wonderful assistance I have received from everyone since Esther came to see me and I didn’t even know this service was available. It makes my mobility around the house a lot safer and I can’t praise them enough for their very professional help.

title: Positive experience
body: My teenage son had surgery in April. Despite Covid restrictions, the surgeon and his team, operating theatre staff and Margaret Duncan ward were very understanding of his needs. I felt like he had excellent, attentive care. Despite I’m sure being very busy everyone took time to listen and regularly checked on him during his stay. On his return home we called the ward with a couple of concerns and again they were helpful and reassuring. I would definitely recommend.

readBy.name: Queen Victoria Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

author: KAMur21
title: Group dietitian session
body: useful session and zoom worked well for the session

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: telescopiumbe43
title: Coeliac powerpoint
body: Was very informative and interesting

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Cadbury1
title: A virtual visit
body: I hadn't seen my auntie lena since she'd been admitted to hospital a week before hand, it had been a sudden illness so it was a shock, with restricted visits the virtual visit tonight was very very precious, just being able to see her and talk to her eased my worries and made me feel so much better. My cousin in Wales also had a virtual visit with her on sunday, without this he would never have been able to visit her. This is a wonderful service that you are offering people, I feel its totally invaluable to people who would not otherwise be able to see their loved ones. Well done yet again NHS.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

title: Efficient and professional
body:
Received both Covid vaccines from this practice, and on both occasions, the process, from booking, to arriving, to receiving the vaccination was flawless. 

Staff were polite and professional, and the whole process was quick and efficient.

In contrast, I accompanied a friend who was referred to a vaccination hub miles away from his catchment area. The process there took over 40 minutes from arrival and was staffed by volunteers whom I can only describe as pedantic, with no real awareness of customer service. The contrast between the staff at Groby Road and the vaccination hub was jarring. 

Well done to the staff at Groby Road Medical Centre for such an efficient and professional experience!

title: GP failed to call
body: After receiving a call from the practice manager to explain why my partner could not have a face to face meeting with a gp because of 3 days of chronic pain, The practice manager said she would receive a call today PM from a GP the call never came. Its totally unacceptable that the practice failed to deliver a call as promised. This now has got to be raised to a higher complaint level,she will now research how the best way forward is to find the right complaints options body through her local MP Dan Jarvis.

author: jazzmm89
title: Thank you to the sonographer
body: My husband and I attended Ayrshire Maternity Unit for our 20 and 32 week ultrasound scan and our sonographer both times was Rebecca (Becky). We would like to say a huge thanks to Becky as she made our experience memorable. We were made to feel very welcome and relaxed, we could tell that she loved her job and we liked that she was as excited as us both times seeing our baby on the scan! Please pass on our thanks.

title: Terrible - failing. Very sad.
body:
3 years ago Longfields were not taking any more patients upon their books. 

Rightly so; capacity had been reached.

They were barely coping then.

Now, with 100's of new houses they have been told to re-open their books and allow new residents to register.

I talked to admin (they have a lot of admin staff); they said they were extremely busy but the NHS Trust insisted they take on new patients.

More GP practices need to be built or this one expanded drastically. Thete are hardly any doctors on the books.

The place is FAILING. 

It takes an hour to reach a receptionist. (Please employ more).

There are no appointments available.

A potential cancer scare and I was told to ring 111 (who cannot refer one to a consultant), so that was poor advice.

A simple repeat annual prescription review has taken 2 MONTHS of waiting for the practice to give me an appointment - still waiting for an appointment.

Doctors are not on site and they seem to be leaving the sinking ship.

Medical waste is piled inside the entrance.

If they are overwhelmed they should seek help.

Trying to seek medical help from this 'establishment' is leading to depression.

The practice is getting WORSE (and is has not been good since 10 years ago).

Please create an action plan and implement it before fatalities unnecessarily occur  (if they have not already occurred).

You are not offering a service that rates 1 out of 10.

One would think we are living in a third world country.

We are not in a third world country.

Why is common sense and my tax and NI contributions not be used to produce a general practice that functions even slightly in a large and expanding town ?

This establishment needs inspecting, an audit carried out and some managers that create a system that works.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: corridordb97
title: Excellent staff
body: Excellent staff! Couldn’t be more accommodating. Very limited lunch choice though. I noticed that only some patients in the ward actually took a lunch, which given that we are either new mums or expecting, I find worrying. Otherwise can’t fault ward 31B or the labour ward.

author: scottishmum1517
title: My daughter
body:
My daughter is nearly 6 and I’m still waiting on her formal autistic diagnosis. Her referral was done on November 2018 and we have only had a consultation call from the community paediatrician on June 2020 but we’ve had no face to face appointment. I’ve been trying to chase this up and yesterday at the speech and language appointment I asked about her referral and it’s came to their attention that my daughter is down on the waiting list for seeing the community paediatrician but she’s not in the list for the NDP. I was told she would be seen by both. This morning I did a bit of investigating to find out why she’s not on the NDP system (it’s been confirmed to me she never was either) all because her previous speech and language therapist didn’t complete the input requested by the community paediatrician.  
My daughter has been failed by speech and language countless times and this is a very important part for her development. She had over 6 months of not being seen by her previous therapist (prior to covid) after being passed onto their caseload. This therapist was not truthful to both myself and my daughter’s school, from denying conversations have taken place to not providing what they said they would. The list is honestly endless but this new revelation is the tip of the iceberg.  
I’ve done 3 placement requests for my daughter to be put in a school with a unit to help with her speech and language all 3 were rejected and after the 3rd I was told no appeal would be heard. School try their best but they simply cannot cope with her. Every day last week I had a phone call to collect my daughter from school and it happened Monday and Tuesday this week to. This is having a huge impact on her education especially when she was on a part time table right up until December last year.  
I’ve been to my local MP, councillor no one wants to know and I’m a total loss what to do. I feel I’m failing my little girl and it doesn’t matter how much noise I make with these different agencies no one wants to know.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students
North Lanarkshire Health & Social Care Partnership

title: Feel at Ease
body:
Staff were so pleasant and understanding.  Very caring
Explained what was going to happen throughout experience and made sure I was always comfortable.
Thank you so much.

title: News of patients when you cannot visit
body:
My father has been on Ward 8 on and off for several weeks. Trying to get through to the ward to speak to someone about diagnosis, prognosis or just how he's getting on is nearly impossible. 
In these times when visiting is not allowed (and I get that) you could perhaps have a phone line or some system where relatives can be given information about their loved ones.

readBy.name: South Tees Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

author: TPPcglbrum
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: A Big Thank You
body:
I would like to start by saying a massive thank you for changing my life and returning me to a person I had lost sight of many years ago.  
My addiction to smoking and cigarettes had limited my life in so many ways. I never believed that anyone could do anything to help me and actually did I ever want helping?  
Joining the CGL Programme enabled me to access my life, see the wider picture and begin to plan positive steps ahead.  
At no point was I made to feel pressured to do anything - in fact, the first time I took part, I didn't want to do anything and thought I was ok.  
Slowly but surely things started to change, the mist cleared, the steps of the staircase were easier to climb, goals (however small) could be achieved.  
Winston supported me all the way and was always friendly, honest and professional - never afraid to have that blunt conversation - when needed - only happened once. And boy did I need it!  
I owe so much to the CGL Programme and Winston. He was always there when I needed him. He always understood what I was going through!  
I must also thank Mark who works alongside Winston. He knew my position and situation and spoke from experience with understanding. It was by talking to Mark that I decided to stop drinking. Mark, you are a star! You helped me so much and I can never thank you enough.  
Following 'the conversation' with Winston who then referred me to Mark, my life changed dramatically.  
I could now see the horizon and even today I feel I am still sailing and continuing to see, seek and discover new horizons that I could never have imagined before.  
I am now 82 days free of alcohol and 47 days smoke free.  
I am now able to get in my car and drive whenever I want, make appointments for late afternoons, go and do whatever I want, when I want.  
It has not been easy and I am sure there will be challenges and hurdles along the way but Winston, Mark and the CGL Programme have given me the tools and strategies to put in place and keep me on this positive, bright journey.  
Thank you again Winston - and like you said - with the best possible intensions, I hope our paths never cross again, and if they ever do it will be nothing but celebratory.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

title: Children’s a&e amazing staff
body: The staff are amazing with children and helped ease nerves they make sure every child is seen to and best care is given

readBy.name: East Kent Hospitals University NHS Foundation Trust

title: Superb maternity care
body: The care myself , husband and baby have received by the maternity team between 22/6-24/6 has been outstanding. What a fantastic team of midwives who despite being very busy took such great personal care of us. I can not fault them . I also felt empowered and involved in decisions surrounding my labour and postnatal care. The labour ward was very busy when we were there but the team were professional and very very hard working. I felt very safe and knew my baby was in very good hands. Thank you to you all for the marvellous job you do and for helping bring my baby into the world

readBy.name: The Newcastle upon Tyne Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

author: petri
title: Depression, Anxiety, Trauma
body: I finally took the plunge to start therapy after a stressful episode and got connected with Mehnaz. She was very challenging and made me reframe some of my self-destructive behavioural patterns. I have had close friends and family members notice that I carry myself slightly differently, but most importantly, I notice those differences myself. My therapist was incredibly attentive and gentle in pushing me out of my comfort zone, and I feel bittersweet about the therapy having ended, but as we've both said on our final session: I have the tools now and I'll continue using them.

author: telescopiumck49
title: Excellent / caring paramedic crew
body: I would like to thank the paramedic crew (forth valley hospital Larbert) who arrived at my house on one day last week, John, Jordan and Devlin who was a trainee. Thank you for reassurance, advice and making me feel at ease after a very frightened episode of severe chest pains. My husband and I are very grateful. You all went above and beyond and explained everything well, much appreciated.

title: Awful postnatal experience
body:
There is much financial investment from CCGs which aren’t visibly apparent in the facilities. MAU needs an overhaul as well as the recovery and postnatal unit. I found the facilities dirty and in poor working order (the toilets) in the ward were frequently clogged. My clinical care prior to giving birth was good and birthing midwives hit and miss, one in particular was amazing.

The nightmare started following birth. Recovery unit whilst waiting for transfer was dirty, midwife had pulled off my canula leaving blood exposed on hands, not hearing my worry about this and walking off. Food given was cold and stale haven’t not eaten for few days.

I was transferred to a hospital bed in the ward where the lights were broken and toilets not working. The alarm didn’t always work and sometimes when it did, staff will not come to help. I had the main light on over my bed, making it difficult to sleep - reported many times not fixed during my long stay and wasn’t offered to change until my last day.

Instead of having open access to showers you have bathrooms in the ward, which is awful if you’ve had surgery needing to climb into the bath and avoid getting incision area wet. 

The worst part of all were the staff. I found most of them uncaring, some extremely rude and left feeling fearful with my newborn. The receptionist was rude as well as one of the kitchen staff. Food isn’t fresh and nutritious. The clinical assistants, including the midwives were shocking. You will regularly hear they were looking after 8 women and run off their feet. Perhaps if they were given fewer patients to look after they may remember why they chose to come into the caring profession and be kind. 

Some midwives pushed their personal agenda for breastfeeding and disregarded clinical advise from doctors to offer formula to manage my child’s clinical condition were confusing, especially being shouted, left me in tears many times. 

Giving birth in lockdown as a first time mum was challenging navigating the system. Finding ones self in the postnatal ward in the situation l was in was traumatising. My husband was only allowed to see me for an hour due to pandemic, which l understand but this should have been extended to provide us with help seeing help from the staff wasn’t always at hand.

There were a handful of midwives and clinical assistants who were caring and although pressured on the whole were kind. The paediatric doctors were wonderful and registrars lovely - I never met a consultant during my stay.

You wouldn’t expect this from a world class centre and it’s a great shame. Unless there is serious improvement in the facilities and attitude of staff, l cannot see myself returning especially now revealing the negative aspect of my experience.

author: trapperhf34
title: Got vaccinated today
body: At John Scott, staff was very friendly, kind and efficient.

author: vickksvapour
title: cancellation policy SHSCT
body:
x 2 cancellation policy is in my opinion somewhat extreme. Trying to rearrange 2nd appointment due to late notice of appointment and work commitments only to be told that it can not be rearranged and has to go back to GP for repeat referral, I feel like this is wasting my time trying to arrange this and GPs time organising this.  
The policy needs looked at again [Unsure about 'Appointments']

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Nicole.S237
title: The Cleft Team
body:
Our son was born in August 2020 and soon after he was born we discovered he had a wide cleft of the sort and hard palate, PRS and hearing impairment. He is now 10 months old and doing amazingly well, but this is all thanks to the amazing cleft team at the Glasgow Children’s Hospital, Shirley and MR Russell.  
The care we received from the day out son was born has been incredible, Shirley was there during the really difficult times with feeding challenges, sleeping issues, pre op support, post op support and she has made the challenging process so much easier for us as a family and for our son’s recovery.  
We feel really lucky that Mr Russell was allocated as our son’s surgeon, he has given him a new palate, the chance of speech and the ability to lead a normal life. We will be forever grateful for the work, care and support given to our son.  
There were really difficult times for our son, us as parents and our older child, who didn’t understand what was happening, but the cleft team have supported the whole family through this, not just our son  
Thank you for all that you have done for us.

author: Clare E
title: My experience
body: From the moment I arrived in Day Elective DHH the service was fantastic. Nursing/HCA staff were so helpful and explained everything to me. They could not have done enough; in particular Mary-Kate, Allison, Catriona and Karen were excellent. In theatres everything was so organised and well explained. Chris the anaesthetic nurse was fantastic as was Piera in recovery (a heated blanket made all the difference). Honestly, they all deserve to be commended for their high standard of care and if I have left any names out it’s only because there were too many amazing staff to mention. Thank you all.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: hazeldreams
title: How nice the staff were
body: Mike the GP has a magic touch. Let him do all the people with needle phobias. Please and thank you: )

author: Naomijst
title: They kept us calm and well informed
body: I just want to thank the staff in paediatric ED in Craigavon Area Hospital. I attended with my toddler who had a minor head injury but unfortunately started to vomit. The care and attention we received was above and beyond. Even though we arrived in the early hours of the morning and they were stretched and busy, every courtesy was shown and we couldn’t have asked for more from them. In a very worrying and stressful time, they kept us calm and well informed. Particularly want to mention Staff Nurses Louise and Dearbhla for their care and attention, and Dr Wylie and Dr Kennedy, their efforts and reassurance meant everything, can’t thank them enough. To all in ED where your work can be under appreciated, I want to say a sincere well done and thank you.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Gardiner1
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Weakness due to ME
body:
I have been suffering with ME for over 28 years and being in lockdown and furlough for 6 months made my weakness worse, so I was referred to Katrina by my Doctor.
Katrina worked with me via phone calls and chatted me through how I needed to slow down, not rush and take small gradual steps to help myself. These tips helped me cope with the good days and bad days.
Katrina also sent me worksheets which were really beneficial to me at the time and now allow me a reference point to refer back too. Katrina did help lift my spirits at the time of our sessions and can not think of anything that Katrina could have done differently.
I would have liked to have had Face to face appointment's but understand why these can not take place during the current situation. This was my first time to use this kind of service and would recommend to use again.

readBy.name: North Lanarkshire Health & Social Care Partnership

author: capellabr66
title: Lack of support
body:
I learned via Pink News that NHS England have stopped lower surgery for trans men due to bureaucracy.  
I contacted various places to ask what was going on and if I could access any mental health support through this ordeal. I contacted my GIC (Sheffield) who said they also learned about it via Pink News. I contacted GDNRSS who were totally unhelpful and basically told me that they couldn't give me any information because it was all confidential. I contacted St Peter's andrology who perform the surgery and they were more helpful but told me they were bound by confidentiality because of NHS England. All places told me that there is no mental health support put in place. It is almost impossible to get mental health support via a GP. Everywhere just passes the buck to another place in an endless circle.  
I am now faced with the possibility of an interminable wait (even longer than the years-long wait I already expected) or perhaps even having to somehow self-fund (I do not have the money for this) for the second half of an operation that I would not have embarked on if I knew I could be left stuck with half a penis after going through the first half of an operation that was already an ordeal.  
NHS England is totally failing in its duty of care to too many people. I hope that someone reads this and actually considers doing something because this situation is absolutely monstrous and disgraceful and it would never be allowed to happen to cis men.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)
Sheffield Health and Social Care NHS Foundation Trust

author: Mclandy
title: Double booked
body: I was appalled to hear my good friend waited from 8 hours for transport, then only on phoning to be told she had been double booked and could not be seen. I would have thought this would have been picked up on their computer and a phone call to her would have been appropriate. Shame!

readBy.name: University Hospitals Bristol and Weston NHS Foundation Trust

title: gone terrible
body: tried to make an appointment for wife and after 5 mins of numerous options and then waiting 15 mins for some one to answer phone i gave up and called 999

title: Terrible
body:
I had a booked appointment at around 10am, GP called me back after 12pm when I was at work and couldn't talk, told that I'm free after 16pm, never received a call back. 
Next day went online to check about my appointment and it counts like I had one already, so I decided to book other appointment but was told I reached my appointment limit, how is this possible if I never had an appointment in first place. 
GP was complete ignorant and waiting time when you already booked appointment are unrealistic. Why then set the time if you cannot call on time?

title: Not listening to request for face to face…
body: I am a GP and have now left the practice due to poor management. Unfortunately I still have family members there who I've encouraged to leave. They have written econsults to try to get a review of their chest symptoms as I believe requires an urgent scan but have been told several times that they have to wait 4-6 weeks until can see a nurse for asthma review. I actually find this worrying as symptoms are deteriorating. I have met in the past several great GPs there so I can only assume this is a management issue. My concerns are ongoing and this issue has still not been dealt with adequately.

author: dolly18
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Anxiety through sore bones and joints after Chemo
body:
I was referred by my Dr due to effects suffered after Chemo and anxiety.
Katrina was brilliant with me from the start. Giving me leaflets to read and all sessions apart from one took place over the phone, the visit was to arrange bed helper for me.
Everything Katrina did for me was very beneficial, from breathing techniques to even helping me to weed my pot plants and now going for regular walks out the back instead of sleeping.
Katrina could not have done any more and I felt great after every call that we had and certainly better than any other sessions I have had in the past for different services. Katrina listened to every detail/complaint I had, and she always had an answer for me, she really was brilliant/

author: Gal25
title: Wonderful care
body:
An urgent assessment at GGH opthalmology clinic ran smoothly with excellent care. Staff were all welcoming and the service ran seamlessly with multiple interventions provided by a multidisciplinary team in a fast and efficient manner. The team were thoughtful, caring and offered person centred care letting me choose my own treatment options in line with my own requirements.  
Dr Jennifer hind was warm, welcoming and generally wonderful and provided a thorough assessment, kept me fully informed and let me make decisions in my care provision.

author: learningtx86
title: Vaccination
body: I have a phobia of needles and am prone to fainting. Whilst waiting in line I started crying. One of the nurses noticed and hugged me and took me to a booth. Two nurses, one was called Dorothy, spoke to me, gave me water and sweets and looked after me. They tried to distract me and make me laugh which is annoying but also very helpful! ! They wheeled me into the next booth where I was vaccinated. I was hysterical, shaking and crying but those two women helped me through. Cannot thank them enough.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: SteveN111
title: great professionalism
body:
From the 999 call to discharge, all the care I received was exemplary.  
I suffered a heart attack and the paramedics were so good, I don't know their names but they could not have done more. Driving along the A1 blue lights flashing, the young man managed to put a cannula in and when we arrived at the Royal, the staff were standing outside waiting for me. Straight into the Cardiac Cath Lab and treated with care and respect. Once the staff there were done, I was transferred to the CCU and once again, the staff could not have done more for me. Colin, my named nurse, was so attentive as were all the other people I came into contact with. Dr Japp explained everything in great detail and made sure I was involved in all the decision making.  
I was then transferred to 103 where I stayed for another day. Whilst the staff were run off their feet and clearly under great pressure, they did their jobs with great professionalism and that ranged from the nursing staff to the ancillary staff and everyone in-between.  
The doctors were informative and responsive to my questions.  
Once I was discharged, the next day I received a phone call from the cardiac rehab team with an appointment for a telephone follow-up the following day.  
All in all, I cannot rate the service highly enough and would like to thank everyone involved in my care.

author: lacertaqs75
title: Bipolar disorder in Ward 12. Hospital for 7 weeks.
body: I was admitted into Lagan valley on a detention. I was admitted on the grounds that I was not fit to be at home by my parents and my partner. I then was a voluntary inpatient but decided along with my parents that it was best for me to be there under the care of the doctor and the nurses. I was discharged in June 2021. I am now safely home and settling into life at home again. It will take some time for me to fully get back on to my feet and back into my job but there are processes there and I will make use of the programmes recommended by the amazing peer advocate team. Which I could not praise enough! They were fantastic. Martin and Kerry-Anne had an amazing rapport with the group and all of us patients. They personally helped me in more ways I could even explain.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: scoreboardkm58
title: Consultation
body: I went for a screening and instantly felt COVID safe and at ease. Not too long of a wait before a lovely lady called my name. We discussed my circumstances since my last visit and since the start of the pandemic and picked up where we left off from pre lockdown with a course of immunisations. General check up for peace of mind and I felt so comfortable the whole way through mainly down to the nurse I’d seen.

author: N_A
title: I found it really helpful
body:
I found it really helpful coming to Pegasus ward as the staff are very kind and hard-working and they helped me in my recovery.  
When I came to the Pegasus ward I found it a bit difficult to settle in but over time because of the activities planned everyday it helped me spend time to try new things and I enjoyed them. The staff and the young people are all very kind and supportive, I got to meet new people and it was nice to speak to them. Everything that we needed was provided and it helped me in my recovery. The environment of the ward was very nice.

author: geminijj74
title: She's not just my nurse
body:
Laurie from the Kilbirnie district nurses is just excellent. She is really good, and soo lovely. I don't even have to go to the door to let her in, she just calls out that its her and lets herself in. She always asks if there is anything else she can do for me that day - but she couldn't do any more for me if she tried! just so, so good.  
I'm so impressed, even with the epidemic and everything, the district nurses have always been there to help me. Every other nurse has been great as well, but I've known Laurie the longest, and its to the point where she's not just my nurse, she's my friend.

author: coordinationme45
title: New Patient
body: I’m a new patient so have never been to the practice but so far they have been very helpful in signing me up.

author: DannySM
title: Possible TIA
body:
Ended up in FVRH outpatients twice last week, having phoned in to 111 with a possible TIA on two occasions - severe, consistent pain in left arm from wrist to shoulder. Very little still happening by the time I got there so first time I was sent away.... second time, the very thorough A& E doctor (sorry.. didn't make a note of his name and so can't praise him personally) referred me into Mr Soane's TIA clinic.  
Experience of seeing Mr Soane was very good... thoroughly professional. He wasn't convinced my experience had been of a TIA as some classic symptoms were missing, but not prepared either to contradict doctor who saw me at the time. Will talk over the experience with GP in terms of lifestyle/prevention/next steps.

author: Aldridge
title: Fear of catching an STD
body:
I phoned the local clinic number and got through to a receptionist who took sime basic detail and that a nurse would call later that day to evaulate my situation.
A few hours later the nurse phoned and did a review of my symptoms and history in a supportive way and then booked an appointment as soon as I could attend the clinic.
My only disappointment was that the clinic was not in my home town (Tamworth) but in Branston so a bit further away but not a problem.
The visit to the clinic was quick and efficient and all the staff helpful and friendly.

author: pyxiszc75
title: Pain management
body:
On monday 21st June i had elective ortho surgery. The surgeon Mr Wong was Fantastic.  
The ward was clean spacious and care was given to the current covid situation. Although having no visitors meant tat little things where difficult like closing the blinds in the room. Not easy to do on crutches!  
Back from theatre and the pain was as expected high. However what wasnt expected was having to repeatedly ask for pain relief! It felt much like begging for pain medication every 4 hrs. At one stage I was asked did I take a lot of medication at home because I needed so much morphine. What exactly was this staff member asking me? In agony and not in good form, this was extremely upsetting? I felt like they were trying to say I had issues. I was left feeling like I couldn't ask for pain relief. Foot surgery is extremely painful which I knew would be the case but to be left feeling like I couldn't ask for help was even more upsetting.  
Also little things like helping a pt on crutches pack to go home would go along way.  
Not all bad. I cant continue without mentioning 2 nurses who helped me through. Gemma and Viji. These girls were brilliant they checking in on me and helped in every way they could. Brilliant nurses who redeemed this experience.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust
Ulster University, Faculty of Life and Health Sciences

author: ospreynf38
title: Covid vaccination
body: Everyone at the centre was so friendly. It was an exceptionally quick and efficient service!

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: correspondencewp75
title: Regular checkup & bloods
body:
I had some repeat blood tests.
The nurses was very nice and kind as always.

author: beiddg96
title: Early pregnancy service
body: I attended with my husband for an early pregnancy scan after I had been referred by my midwife. The midwife, Sharon, and the sonographers were so supportive. Gave very clear explanations about what to expect, and although the outcome for us was not as we had hoped, we couldn’t have faulted the care they provided to us. Thank you to you all for your kindness.

readBy.name: Sherwood Forest Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

author: Matayou84
title: 999 call
body:
Had an altercation with a cow,  
Paramedics in the ambulance were brand new, staff member that dealt with me in the Dr Gray's hospital brand new, however the care and attention I received was horrendous, it was a head back and chest injury, and all I was given was my stitches and punted out the door, no concussion check or xray or anything, the next day when I got up my wife had to take me to A&E in Inverness, turned out I've serious internal bruising and broken ribs, and I also received the drugs from Inverness and the medical advice I should have received from Elgin.

author: Mumofmany
title: My son's injury
body:
My young son had suffered a nasty cycling injury and was seen in RBHSC emergency department on a busy weekend.  
He was frightened and in pain. We were worried about a time critical injury which might need surgery. He was rapidly assessed by a professional and compassionate triage nurse, the resident emergency medicine consultant, a surgeon, and a radiologist who performed an ultrasound. He was also seen by a radiographer who gave him a great sticker and updated us on when the ultrasound would happen to relieve our concerns. Several other nurses and healthcare assistants performed observations and gave him pain relief. The consultant in EM, surgeon and radiologist were particularly memorable for their clarity of explanation to both myself and my son.  
All the staff dealt with him compassionately, professionally and showed good humour even in the face of a busy department. In many ways their encounter with us will have been unremarkable to them. Not so for us. This where the magic of healthcare really happens. In those small moments of seemingly unremarkable care delivery, there is excellence that we just don't take time to notice and amplify.  
I hope it is useful to reflect these everyday encounters back to healthcare staff to help them appreciate the extraordinary work they do in these extraordinary times. We are very appreciative. Thank you.  
[Unsure about 'Nurses']  
[Unsure about 'Other staff']  
[Unsure about 'Team work']

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: Jothetennisgirl
title: Radiotherapy Lucky Number 7
body:
I attended for my radiotherapy treatment a few weeks ago, I was nervous and anxious about what it was going to be like.  
I had been through surgery and chemotherapy but this was another daunting step on my journey to recovery. I was welcomed by a lovely young radiographer called Emma on what I call the “lucky number 7 machine “  
I struck gold , Emma talked me through everything putting me at complete ease, she listened to my worries and concerns and took the time to answer my questions.  
The continuity of care was outstanding, having had a few of my treatments privately I was pleasantly surprised that I had Emma for almost all of my 10 treatments, it was clear they are a very busy team but the whole team made me feel like a person not just a number in what is a busy department.  
All the radiographers on number 7 were fantastic, but a special thanks to Emma she guided me through a very difficult time, she was kind, knowledgable and clearly very respected by her colleagues. I could not have had a better experience .  
Thank you to all on Lucky Number 7.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: Faa1621
title: Transition Ward
body:
I have recently had a stay on this new ward due to my baby being re- admitted. The ward has been set up to keep mothers and babies together while they receive treatment out with neonatal. I cannot praise this service enough. All of the staff are helpful, friendly and I felt that my baby and I were very well looked after day and night. The staff are fantastic at providing support at what can be a very worrying time for parents, not to mention the education they provide parents with on how best to care for their babies in order to help them get better.  
I genuinely hope that this service will continue as it’s invaluable. I felt safe, kept up to date with my babies condition at all times and very well supported throughout.

author: mineralpf75
title: The staff were tremendous
body:
All the staff were tremendous, they made the experience bearable while feeling looked after.  
![Image](https://www.careopinion.org.uk/resources/posting-images/opinions/078cd5b165d54c73a785338b61ab8afd.jpg)

author: jazzty65
title: Vaccine
body: I was very nervous at the start however all the staff have been very helpful and made me feel more comfortable

author: Blossom43
title: Colonoscopy
body: Dr Darroch and her team are amazing. I was put at ease straight away. We are lucky to have such a wonderful hospital on our doorstep. Thank you

author: Mary12345
title: Anxiety and anger
body: I was struggling with anxiety, verging on depression. I was able to do a course entirely online, with phone calls where I needed it to get my anxiety in hand. Mid way through the treatment the anxiety seemed to develop into anger and frustration and straight away my counselor had put in an appointment with me and updated what I needed help with. It's definitely still on going process and not an overnight fix but it was such a massive leap in the right direction.
